channel.title: How can i make a page password protected

item.title: How can i make a page password protected
item.dc:creator: @XxKanexX Kane.
item.description:
@XxKanexX wrote:

[quote=“sppt, post:6, topic:117889”][quote author=XxKanexX link=topic=167187.msg1555594#msg1555594 date=1183127613]
[php]

<?php $u = array('user1', 'user2'); $p = array('pass1', 'pass2'); $user = $_POST['username']; $pass = $_POST['password']; $Success = false; if(in_array($user, $u) && in_array($pass, $p)) { $Success = true; } ?> " method = "POST"> Username:

Password:

<?php if ($Success == true){ echo ""; } else { exit; } ?>

[/php]
[/quote]
edited it a littl bit ;)[/quote]
But, they’re not matching to the position.

If they typed the wrong pass, but someone else had it, it’d also log in.

Read full topic
item.source: How can i make a page password protected

item.title: How can i make a page password protected
item.dc:creator: @Rawrness Rawrness
item.description:
@Rawrness wrote:

Just to addon to what has been said already. When you’re posting variables (for security, and to prevent injections) you’ll want to use addslashes() or stripslashes() – On top of that, if you’re using MySQL you’ll want to use mysql_real_escape_string().

or simply htmlspecialchars()

Read full topic

item.source: How can i make a page password protected

item.title: How can i make a page password protected
item.dc:creator: @XxKanexX Kane.
item.description:
@XxKanexX wrote:

Instead of using Database’s or whatnot, a simple PHP one could be:

<?php
  $u = array('user1', 'user2');
  $p = array('pass1', 'pass2');

  $user = $_POST['username'];
  $pass = $_POST['password'];
  $Success = false;

  for ($i=0;$i<sizeof($u);$i++){
    if ($u[$i] == $user && $p[$i] == $pass){
      $Success = true;
      echo "<noscript>";
    }
  }
?>

<form action = "<?php echo $PHP_SELF; ?>" method = "POST">
Username:<br><input type = "text" name = "username"><br>
Password:<br><input type = "password" name = "password"><br>
<input type = "Submit" value = "Login">

<?php
  if ($Success == true){ echo "</noscript>"; } else { exit; }
?>

You have Successfully logged in, <?php echo $user; ?><br>
Put random junk here.<br>
Yay.<br>
Penis.<br>
Vagina.<br>
69.<br>

User: user1 or user2
Pass: pass1 or pass2

You can add more, if you wish.
But, if you want it like a members thing where people join, MySQL would work, or create a PHP database. ;D

I made an Example here:
http://kaney.freehostia.com/random/testlogin.php

Read full topic

You could use a .htacess to set a directory password protected or if you have cPanel go to password protect directorys.

Or just make it load users and passwords from a mysql database.
